'''Ronnie Baker Brooks''' (born January 23, 1967)<ref name="Hanson"/> is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[soul blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. He was a respected club performer in Chicago, before recording three solo albums for Watchdog Records.  The son of fellow Chicago blues musician [[Lonnie Brooks]],<ref name="Torch"/> he is the brother of another blues guitarist, [[Wayne Baker Brooks]].

[[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Andy Whitman, described Brooks as "... a better than average soul singer, a fine blues interpreter, and a monster guitarist with an ample supply of technique and passion."<ref name="Torch">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=the-torch-r852708/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Torch'' > Review |accessdate=March 20, 2012 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>

==Life and career==
He was born '''Rodney Dion Baker''' in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]].<ref name="History">{{cite web |url=http://www.thehistorymakers.com/biography/biography.asp?bioindex=1115&category=Musicmakers&occupation=Blues%20Musician&name=Ronnie%20Baker%20Brooks |title=Ronnie Baker Brooks Biography |author= |date=August 17, 2005 |work= |publisher=Thehistorymakers.com |accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref>

At the age of nine, he first appeared on stage playing guitar alongside his father.<ref name="Hanson"/> In 1985, Brooks graduated from [[Hales Franciscan High School]].<ref name="History"/> He learned to play [[bass guitar]] and joined his father's band in 1986. Two years later [[Alligator Records]] released Brooks father's [[live album]], ''Live from Chicago: Bayou Lightning Strikes'', which included Ronnie Baker Brooks guitar work. He was then part of Alligator Records 20th Anniversary Tour, and performed alongside [[Koko Taylor]], [[Elvin Bishop]], and [[Lil' Ed Williams]].<ref name="History"/>  By 1998 Brooks had gone solo,<ref name="Hanson"/> and his debut [[album]] ''Golddigger'', was released the same year on the Watchdog [[record label]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=golddigger-r636324|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Golddigger'' > Overview |accessdate=March 20, 2012 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> It was [[record producer|produced]] by [[Janet Jackson]].<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| pages= 131-2
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref> Brooks was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in 2000 for 'Best New Artist'.<ref name="Hanson"/> His second album, ''Take Me Witcha'', followed in May 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=take-me-witcha-r537699|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Take Me Witcha'' > Overview |accessdate=March 20, 2012 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> 

Brooks most recent album was ''Torch'' (2006).  The ''[[Boston Herald]]'' described it as "Ferocious and unrelenting, ''The Torch'' may be
the year's best blues album..." The album included guest contributions from Lonnie Brooks, [[Eddy Clearwater]], [[Jimmy Johnson (blues guitarist)|Jimmy Johnson]], [[Willie Kent]], and [[Al Kapone]], and was produced by [[Jellybean Johnson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ronniebakerbrooks.com/ |title=Ronnie Baker Brooks |author=''[[Boston Herald]]'' |date= |work= |publisher=Ronniebakerbrooks.com |accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name="BluesWax">{{cite web |url=http://bluesrevue.com/2011/03/blues-bytes-ronnie-baker-brooks-3-11-11/# |title=BluesWax Sittin’ In With Ronnie Baker Brooks; Feelin’ It from All Angles |author=Eric Wrisley |date=March 10, 2011 |work=BluesWax |publisher=Bluesrevue.com |accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref>

When on occasion, Ronnie's younger brother Wayne Baker Brooks joined him and his father on stage, they were billed as the Brooks Family Band.<ref name="BluesWax"/> In 2007, Brooks played at the [[Notodden Blues Festival]], and at both [[Memphis in May]] and the [[Musikfest]] in 2009. In August 2010, Brooks co-wrote three tracks with [[Chris Beard]] for the latter's ''Who I Am and What I Do'' on Electro Glide Records.<ref name="Chicago">{{cite web |url=http://chicagobluesmusicnews.blogspot.com/2010/08/chris-beard-and-electro-glide-records.html |title=Chris Beard and Electro Glide Records |author= |date=August 17, 2011 |work=Chicago Blues News |publisher=Chicagobluesmusicnews.blogspot.com |accessdate=December 27, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Beard">{{cite web |url=http://chrisbeard1.com/drupal/?q=node/3 |title=Chris Beard Biography |author= |date=November 2009 |work= |publisher=Chrisbeard1.com |accessdate=December 27, 2011}}</ref>

In 2012 blues reporter, David Brais, declared Brooks "blues royalty".  Brais reported, "His particular style of Chicago blues has been performed on stages around the world. It honors the true torch bearers of this unique sound which includes Willie Dixon, Buddy Guy, B.B. King, Luther Allison and his father."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jammagazine.com/mf201201-ronnie-baker-brooks.aspx |title=Ronnie Baker Brooks: Keeping The Blues Alive, Family Style.  JAM Magazine Speaks Candidly With Blues Royalty, Ronnie Baker Brooks |last1=Baris |first1=David |date=January 2012 |website=jammagazine.com |publisher=JAM Magazine Online |accessdate=October 21, 2013}}</ref>

Brooks lives in [[Dolton, Illinois]], and is a regular at Artis's Lounge on Chicago's South Side. <ref name="History"/>
